Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Metapopulation and metacommunity dynamics in a changing spatial and environmental mosaic - The importance of dispersal and gene flow
Award.AbstractNarration:
Water development projects have transformed aquatic landscapes by changing vegetation, altering seasonality of wetlands, and increasing connectivity via canals. The ecological and evolutionary effects of these changes on aquatic plants and animals are poorly understood, but will likely become more common in the coming decades. This project will make use of 70-year records of the largest water development project in U.S. history to determine how changes in water flow and amount have altered the ecology and evolution of small aquatic animals. An exciting part of the study involves resurrecting these animals from eggs buried in mud for up to 70 years. Their genes will be compared to modern-day individuals to understand what changes have taken place and why those changes have occurred. Graduate and undergraduate students will be mentored, learning cutting-edge genetic techniques, experimental design, statistical analyses, and scientific writing. Results will be communicated to the public through outreach to public schools, collaboration with volunteer citizen scientists, a blog and a website.

Understanding the structure of spatial processes is a critical need in ecology. Dispersal is one such process and a primary mechanism by which species respond to a rapidly changing environment; it is also important in determining the structure of communities and functioning of ecosystems. However, understanding dispersal's role can be confounded by rapid adaptation of species, which is affected by the spatial structure of the environment and priority effects. The goal of this study is to measure ecological and evolutionary responses of invertebrate populations across a period of change in a complex environmental mosaic, using a new approach: landscape paleogenetics. Hypotheses will be tested using the Columbia Basin Project as an extraordinarily large experimental system. The study will exploit a unique feature of some invertebrates, prolonged dormancy, to trace population-level shifts over decades of changes in water distribution. A combination of landscape surveys, historical ecological data going back 70 years, DNA analysis, and landscape genetics will be employed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Human alterations of natural systems can greatly affect the spatial and environmental landscape in which biological communities are embedded. Water development projects have transformed aquatic landscapes, including fragmenting habitats, altering environmental conditions, and increasing connectivity via canals. The effects of these hydrologic changes on interconnected populations and communities, and the ecological and evolutionary processes that govern them, are poorly understood, yet this type of water development is prevalent across the globe and expected to grow in the coming decades. Thus, hydrologic alterations represent a type of natural experiment, where the spatial and environmental landscape of aquatic populations and communities are altered by human activities.

The project asked how water development has changed population connectivity and ability to adapt to altered environmental conditions by comparing historical and modern-day population and community structure.  We compared historical data on invertebrate communities collected prior to water development to contemporary community structure. We found that over time communities in different waterbodies have become more similar to each other in regions where connectivity has increased compared to regions where connectivity has not changed.  This homogenization has implications for adaptation to future environmental changes, as the loss of species with unique traits may hinder adaptation to novel conditions. The levels of homogenization that we document are one of the highest observed in nature and represent a critical real-world test of the effects of increasing connectivity.

In order to test whether this homogenization effect also exists at the population level, we chose to study the keystone species Daphnia, also known as the water flea.  Keystone species have oversized effects on their communities and thus play an important role in ecosystem functioning. We collected populations of Daphnia from the bottom of lakes, where they exist in a prolonged state of hibernation.  We collected these so-called ?resting eggs? from the top layers of sediment, representing contemporary time periods, and from the bottom layers of sediment, representing historical time periods pre-dating the period of water development.  We extracted the DNA from these miniscule eggs and examined the: 1) diversity of genotypes; and 2) how similar populations are in different lakes that vary in their degree of connectivity. We found that individual lake populations of Daphnia are diverse, indicating that novel genotypes are able to integrate into populations in these lakes. Lakes that were more highly connected showed stronger evidence for gene flow compared to lakes that were not connected.  The overall between-lake population diversity indicates a larger amount of dispersal than was originally hypothesized, which could be a signal of dispersal between lakes by birds or human activity. Further research in this system would strengthen this hypothesis. 

 

Broader Impacts: One peer-reviewed publication, seven conference presentations or posters, a teaching module, a data paper, a collaborative group report, a citizen science manual, and a science outreach article resulted from this award, involving two Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU) students, one PhD student, two MS students, three undergraduate students, and one post-bac student, in addition to the PI.  We placed a high priority on training students who are underrepresented in science, including females, first generation, Hispanic, and African American students. We provided students with a broad set of skills that will be useful in research as well as the professional workforce, including data collection, analysis, laboratory methods, data management, manuscript writing, and presentation of results through peer-reviewed manuscripts and oral and poster presentations at local to international conferences.

We engaged the public in numerous ways, including blog postings, training citizen science volunteers, writing about our research in magazines, and developing a teaching module to use DNA to track the spread of invasive species.

We made our data available to the public in open access repositories.
